climbs.name: When Electricity Came to Seven Pines

content.description: Mantle onto the boulder and crank tiny crystals to good holds up higher.
content.location: 30 yards north of the Seven Pines Arete

content.description: Starts on obvious Spock crack/ pocket and incut edge. Use magic skills to get to the jug on the lip and then topout the huge jug-covered slab.
content.location: In a cluster of boulders left of the trail, a little ways up past 7 Pines Arête/Last Survivors.

content.description: A thin crack problem with a sloper topout.
content.location: 25 yards further downhill past the Makido boulder.

content.description: The left arete has balancy moves on excellent rock.
content.location: 30 yards north (behind) the Seven Pines Arete.

content.description: Step off a small boulder and follow a cool sequence up the beautiful wall. The crux is the last move.
content.location: This boulder is about a mile up the trail in a cluster of giant boulders 50 yards north of the trail.  The climb faces northeast.

content.description: Climb the scoops 6’ left of the Seven Pines Arete.  Fun, good rock, good warmup for the climbs next to it or on the Snake Oil boulder just behind.

The classic overhanging arete. Tricky down low and cool jugs up high. Very good rock.

There is also a cool vertical face problem 6' left of the arete.
content.location: 50 yards uphill from Outrageous Fortune, behind large pine trees.

content.description:
Climb classic knobs up the middle of the face.  Great problem on cool-looking, high quality rock.

You can also do a short mantle problem over the bulge on the left side of the face at about v1.
content.location: This problem is 100 yards north of the trail, about 3/4 miles from the trailhead.

content.description:
A short but sweet dyno problem on great rock.  Sit start, crank from the low rail to a second rail, then pull over the bulge on positive holds.

Nahmenou is a character my son invented - the enigmatic proprietor of a mythical dojo specializing in super powers.

A fun face problem on good rock.

"Makido" was how my son pronounced the word tomato, as a toddler.
content.location: At the "Little Lunge", hang a right and go downhill into the forest.  After a minute or two you'll see a large block with an orange face up on the hillside to your right.  Makido is on the back of this boulder.

content.description: Pull on with sharp finger locks and lunge for a bucket at the lip.
content.location: A few minutes past Outrageous Fortune, next to the trail, in the notch behind a small granite peak.

climbs.name: The Last Survivors of the Pleistocene Epoch

content.description:
A beautiful sit start in the middle of the face that eventually links into the stand start 7 Pines Arête. Starts on the middle xenolith feature and climbs perfect rock up crimps and pinches into the stand start and top out on good holds. One of the best of it's relative difficulty in the San Jacintos. Video of an early repeat here:

youtu.be/s8sLL0u_v8o
content.protection: A handful of pads is nice.

content.description: Climb the wave-shaped arete of the precarious boulder.  Don't tip it over.
content.location: 100 yards northwest of the Sleeping Giant.

content.description: A great problem. Insecure moves that feel more like a route than a boulder problem.
content.location: Midway between the last hairpin and the girl scout camp. 20 yards north of the road. Problem faces east.
On the boulder next to "Outrageous Fortune."
